column2: Then Arthur knew that Sir Bedivere had indeed spoken the truth, and the dying King put one more command upon him--namely to bear him to the shore of the lake where he had thrown Excalibur.
column3: Then Arthur knew that Sir Bedivere had indeed spoken the truth, and the dying King put one more command upon him-namely to bear him to the shore of the lake where he had thrown Excalibur.

column2: As they approached the shore a barge was seen cleaving the water without visible motive power, and on the barge which was draped all in black were four damsels who wept bitterly.
column3: As they approached the shore a barge was seen cleaving the water without visible motive power, and on the barge which was draped all in black were four damsels who wept bitterly.

column2: When the prow of the barge reached the shore, Arthur commanded Sir Bedivere to lay him on it--and at once it moved out into the mists of the lake with the black robed figures bending over the King.
column3: When the prow of the barge reached the shore, Arthur commanded Sir Bedivere to lay him on it-and at once it moved out into the mists of the lake with the black robed figures bending over the King.

column2: And Arthur called out to Sir Bedivere in farewell, telling him that he was going to Avalon either to die or to be healed of his grievous wound, and he asked Sir Bedivere to pray for his immortal soul.
column3: And Arthur called out to Sir Bedivere in farewell, telling him that he was going to Avalon either to die or to be healed of his grievous wound, and he asked Sir Bedivere to pray for his immortal soul.

column2: From that day Arthur was not seen again, although many believed that he would come back and rescue his countrymen when dangers beset them; and to-day the legends of Arthur leave it doubtful if he will return or not.
column3: From that day Arthur was not seen again, although many believed that he would come back and rescue his countrymen when dangers beset them; and to day the legends of Arthur leave it doubtful if he will return or not.

column2: But the great King as well as the realm that he ruled over have been lost forever in the mists of time.
column3: But the great King as well as the realm that he ruled over have been lost forever in the mists of time.

column2: And the story of Arthur is ended.
column3: And the story of Arthur is ended.

column2: CHAPTER V
column3: CHAPTER five

column2: MOHAMMED
column3: MOHAMMED

column2: The Arabs are a dark skinned people that live near or on the great deserts of Arabia, one of the hottest and most desolate regions of the world.
column3: The Arabs are a dark skinned people that live near or on the great deserts of Arabia, one of the hottest and most desolate regions of the world.

column2: They have lived there for thousands of years in roving tribes and many of their traits and manners have come from their association with the desert, and the hardships that they have been obliged to undergo in making their journeys upon its fiery sands.
column3: They have lived there for thousands of years in roving tribes and many of their traits and manners have come from their association with the desert, and the hardships that they have been obliged to undergo in making their journeys upon its fiery sands.

column2: Thousands of years ago the Arabs had a religion that was not entirely different from that of the Jews.
column3: Thousands of years ago the Arabs had a religion that was not entirely different from that of the Jews.

column2: As the years passed, however, they began to turn away from the old beliefs and to worship stone idols. These idols were set up in their principal cities and villages, notably in the city of Mecca, where there also remained a temple, built in the time of the older religion, that the Arabs still held to be sacred.
column3: As the years passed, however, they began to turn away from the old beliefs and to worship stone idols. These idols were set up in their principal cities and villages, notably in the city of Mecca, where there also remained a temple, built in the time of the older religion, that the Arabs still held to be sacred.

column2: As the Arabian tribes were very different from each other in many ways, it was only natural that their religion should grow different also. Some men worshipped the fire and some worshipped the stars.
column3: As the Arabian tribes were very different from each other in many ways, it was only natural that their religion should grow different also. Some men worshipped the fire and some worshipped the stars.

column2: Some became Jews or Christians.
column3: Some became Jews or Christians.

column2: For the most part, however, they worshipped stone images and many wise men preached and labored among them in vain to bring back the old religion of their fathers.
column3: For the most part, however, they worshipped stone images and many wise men preached and labored among them in vain to bring back the old religion of their fathers.

column2: Such was the state of affairs when a child was born in the city of Mecca who was destined to become one of the greatest prophets of the world, and draw all the Arabs into a single religion that would spread as far as Spain and India.
column3: Such was the state of affairs when a child was born in the city of Mecca who was destined to become one of the greatest prophets of the world, and draw all the Arabs into a single religion that would spread as far as Spain and India.

column2: This child was named Mohammed, and he was born five hundred and seventy years after the death of Christ.
column3: This child was named Mohammed, and he was born five hundred and seventy years after the death of Christ.

column2: His father, Abdallah, died soon after he was born, and Mohammed's mother, according to custom, gave the baby into the charge of a nurse who might rear him in the free, open air of the desert where Arabs believed that children became strong and vigorous.
column3: His father, Abdallah, died soon after he was born, and Mohammed's mother, according to custom, gave the baby into the charge of a nurse who might rear him in the free, open air of the desert where Arabs believed that children became strong and vigorous.

column2: Mohammed was strong in many ways, but had one great physical failing: he was often seized with fits of a kind that nowadays would be ascribed to the disease called epilepsy.
column3: Mohammed was strong in many ways, but had one great physical failing: he was often seized with fits of a kind that nowadays would be ascribed to the disease called epilepsy.

column2: In those days, however, these fits were thought to be the work of devils who entered into and possessed the body.
column3: In those days, however, these fits were thought to be the work of devils who entered into and possessed the body.

column2: When he was six years old his mother died and he was brought up by his grandfather, Abd al-Muttalib, a poor man, but one who was greatly respected by everybody that knew him.
column3: When he was six years old his mother died and he was brought up by his grandfather, Abd al Muttalib, a poor man, but one who was greatly respected by everybody that knew him.

column2: Abd al-Muttalib put him to work.
column3: Abd al Muttalib put him to work.

column2: When he grew old enough, he watched the flocks of the people of Mecca, and gained a meager livelihood by doing this.
column3: When he grew old enough, he watched the flocks of the people of Mecca, and gained a meager livelihood by doing this.

column2: He had no schooling, but once or twice had the opportunity to travel, when he went with his uncle to southern Arabia and to Syria, where he saw people different from those of Mecca and learned of many different forms of religion.
column3: He had no schooling, but once or twice had the opportunity to travel, when he went with his uncle to southern Arabia and to Syria, where he saw people different from those of Mecca and learned of many different forms of religion.

column2: When Mohammed was twenty-five years old there befell a change in his fortunes.
column3: When Mohammed was twenty five years old there befell a change in his fortunes.

column2: In this year he entered the service of a rich widow, whose name was Kadijah, and went with her to the great fairs and bazaars on which journeys, perhaps, he acted as her camel driver.
column3: In this year he entered the service of a rich widow, whose name was Kadijah, and went with her to the great fairs and bazaars on which journeys, perhaps, he acted as her camel driver.

column2: Kadijah soon fell in love with the young man of bright, piercing eyes and thoughtful demeanor, and one day she drew Mohammed aside and told him that she loved him, offering to become his wife and to give him her hand in marriage.
column3: Kadijah soon fell in love with the young man of bright, piercing eyes and thoughtful demeanor, and one day she drew Mohammed aside and told him that she loved him, offering to become his wife and to give him her hand in marriage.

column2: By marrying Kadijah Mohammed became rich.
column3: By marrying Kadijah Mohammed became rich.

column2: He managed his wife's affairs at Mecca with great success, and became greatly respected there as a man of business.
column3: He managed his wife's affairs at Mecca with great success, and became greatly respected there as a man of business.

column2: He and Kadijah had six children, four girls and two boys, but both of the boys died in their infancy.
column3: He and Kadijah had six children, four girls and two boys, but both of the boys died in their infancy.

column2: But Mohammed was soon marked as being different from other men.
column3: But Mohammed was soon marked as being different from other men.

column2: He spent a great deal of his time in religious contemplation and would go off by himself into the solitude of the mountains, to think and ponder without interruption.
column3: He spent a great deal of his time in religious contemplation and would go off by himself into the solitude of the mountains, to think and ponder without interruption.

column2: When he was forty years old he went one day to a mountain called Hira which was not far from Mecca.
column3: When he was forty years old he went one day to a mountain called Hira which was not far from Mecca.

column2: And here a trance came upon him and in the night he believed that he saw the angel Gabriel.
column3: And here a trance came upon him and in the night he believed that he saw the angel Gabriel.

column2: The angel was surrounded by a flaming aureole and in his hand he held a scroll of fire from which he commanded Mohammed to read.
column3: The angel was surrounded by a flaming aureole and in his hand he held a scroll of fire from which he commanded Mohammed to read.

column2: Now Mohammed knew not how to read or write, but to his amazement he found that the words on the scroll were quite plain to him, and he read a wonderful message that proclaimed the glory and the greatness of God, whom he called Allah.
column3: Now Mohammed knew not how to read or write, but to his amazement he found that the words on the scroll were quite plain to him, and he read a wonderful message that proclaimed the glory and the greatness of God, whom he called Allah.

column2: Mohammed was frightened by what he had seen; he thought that perhaps the form of the angel had been taken by some evil spirit to lead him on to his undoing.
column3: Mohammed was frightened by what he had seen; he thought that perhaps the form of the angel had been taken by some evil spirit to lead him on to his undoing.

column2: But at last he had another vision in which Gabriel came to him again and called upon him to arise and preach the word of Allah throughout the land and bring back to the Arabs the faith of their fathers and the worship of a single god.
column3: But at last he had another vision in which Gabriel came to him again and called upon him to arise and preach the word of Allah throughout the land and bring back to the Arabs the faith of their fathers and the worship of a single god.

column2: And then for the first time Mohammed believed his visions and thought himself God's Prophet, and he called the new faith that he was to teach the faith of _Islam_, which means righteousness.
column3: And then for the first time Mohammed believed his visions and thought himself God's Prophet, and he called the new faith that he was to teach the faith of underscore Islam underscore, which means righteousness.

column2: Mohammed went back to Kadijah and told her what he had seen.
column3: Mohammed went back to Kadijah and told her what he had seen.

column2: He said he was chosen by Allah to spread his faith over the land, and he himself was a prophet greater than any other in the world.
column3: He said he was chosen by Allah to spread his faith over the land, and he himself was a prophet greater than any other in the world.

column2: Kadijah was a true and faithful wife and loved Mohammed better than herself.
column3: Kadijah was a true and faithful wife and loved Mohammed better than herself.

column2: She believed that he spoke the truth, and looked upon him as some one who through God's means had become more than a man.
column3: She believed that he spoke the truth, and looked upon him as some one who through God's means had become more than a man.

column2: At first Mohammed did not try to preach his new faith to the people of Mecca, but contented himself with teaching the word of Allah to his nearest relatives.
column3: At first Mohammed did not try to preach his new faith to the people of Mecca, but contented himself with teaching the word of Allah to his nearest relatives.

column2: Most of them believed in him, but one of his uncles called him a fool and would have nothing to do with the new religion.
column3: Most of them believed in him, but one of his uncles called him a fool and would have nothing to do with the new religion.

column2: After four years of teaching Mohammed had only converted to the new belief forty people, who were mostly men of low degree or slaves.
column3: After four years of teaching Mohammed had only converted to the new belief forty people, who were mostly men of low degree or slaves.

column2: He then thought that Allah called upon him to go forth publicly and preach his new belief to the entire world.
column3: He then thought that Allah called upon him to go forth publicly and preach his new belief to the entire world.

column2: And soon afterward Mohammed could have been seen in the market place preaching the word of Allah.
column3: And soon afterward Mohammed could have been seen in the market place preaching the word of Allah.

column2: The faith that Mohammed taught was very much like the faith that we ourselves believe in.
column3: The faith that Mohammed taught was very much like the faith that we ourselves believe in.

column2: That is, it was much more like the religion of Christ than the worship of idols or the belief of the Romans and Greeks in gods and goddesses, or the worship of fire or the stars.
column3: That is, it was much more like the religion of Christ than the worship of idols or the belief of the romans and Greeks in gods and goddesses, or the worship of fire or the stars.

column2: Mohammed preached that there was one God only, and that this God was greater than all things.
column3: Mohammed preached that there was one God only, and that this God was greater than all things.

column2: If you died and had led a righteous life you went to Paradise; if you had been wicked you went to the lower regions to undergo eternal punishment.
column3: If you died and had led a righteous life you went to Paradise; if you had been wicked you went to the lower regions to undergo eternal punishment.

column2: And there were a great many things in Mohammed's religion that any one would do well to follow, for he preached that God was merciful and his people on earth must be merciful also, that cleanliness was next to Godliness and that all his followers must wash themselves before they prayed.
column3: And there were a great many things in Mohammed's religion that any one would do well to follow, for he preached that God was merciful and his people on earth must be merciful also, that cleanliness was next to Godliness and that all his followers must wash themselves before they prayed.

column2: In many ways, however, the Mohammedan faith was not so pure as the Christian faith, for the Heaven that Mohammed believed in was a place of feasting and merriment, but little else, and Mohammed also believed that it was right to teach his religion by the sword.
column3: In many ways, however, the Mohammedan faith was not so pure as the Christian faith, for the Heaven that Mohammed believed in was a place of feasting and merriment, but little else, and Mohammed also believed that it was right to teach his religion by the sword.

column2: In this, however, Mohammed's followers became more zealous than he had ever thought of being, and we must remember also that Christians of those days did not hesitate to use the sword, themselves.
column3: In this, however, Mohammed's followers became more zealous than he had ever thought of being, and we must remember also that Christians of those days did not hesitate to use the sword, themselves.

column2: To spread the faith Mohammed set about preparing a great book which was to be the bible of those who believed in his religion.
column3: To spread the faith Mohammed set about preparing a great book which was to be the bible of those who believed in his religion.

column2: This book was called the Koran.
column3: This book was called the Koran.

column2: Because Mohammed could not write and still produced this marvelous book, which contained the word of Allah, he claimed that he was divinely inspired.
column3: Because Mohammed could not write and still produced this marvelous book, which contained the word of Allah, he claimed that he was divinely inspired.

column2: It is thought, however, that he was helped in preparing the Koran by one of his disciples who could read and write.
column3: It is thought, however, that he was helped in preparing the Koran by one of his disciples who could read and write.

column2: When Mohammed prepared the Koran there was no paper, and writing materials were far removed from the Arabs who made little use of them. So Mohammed was compelled, as we are told, to write the Koran on any material that came to hand.
column3: When Mohammed prepared the Koran there was no paper, and writing materials were far removed from the Arabs who made little use of them. So Mohammed was compelled, as we are told, to write the Koran on any material that came to hand.

column2: He wrote it on pieces of stone and strips of leather, and on dried palm leaves,--and some of the verses were even written on the bleached shoulder blades of sheep.
column3: He wrote it on pieces of stone and strips of leather, and on dried palm leaves,--and some of the verses were even written on the bleached shoulder blades of sheep.

column2: Anything that could hold a mark was used by him as writing material, and the verses were later collected and made into a book by his disciples.
column3: Anything that could hold a mark was used by him as writing material, and the verses were later collected and made into a book by his disciples.

column2: When Mohammed commenced to preach before the people, the citizens of Mecca looked on him as a madman.
column3: When Mohammed commenced to preach before the people, the citizens of Mecca looked on him as a madman.

column2: They did not molest him, however, because they held him to be a worthless dreamer who could do no harm to anybody.
column3: They did not molest him, however, because they held him to be a worthless dreamer who could do no harm to anybody.

column2: But as weeks went by, and the number of those who became converted to his faith grew larger, the wise men who still believed in the great stone idols named Hubal and Uzza began to grow afraid.
column3: But as weeks went by, and the number of those who became converted to his faith grew larger, the wise men who still believed in the great stone idols named Hubal and Uzza began to grow afraid.

column2: They were too cowardly to molest Mohammed, because he was a rich man and was protected by his uncle who had much influence among them,--but they vented their spite on the humbler people who followed him and who were unable to protect themselves.
column3: They were too cowardly to molest Mohammed, because he was a rich man and was protected by his uncle who had much influence among them,--but they vented their spite on the humbler people who followed him and who were unable to protect themselves.

column2: So it came to pass that the poor men who were Mohammedans, particularly the slaves, were made to suffer dreadful tortures.
column3: So it came to pass that the poor men who were Mohammedans, particularly the slaves, were made to suffer dreadful tortures.

column2: They were scourged with whips and placed all day in the burning sunshine without a drop of water for their thirst.
column3: They were scourged with whips and placed all day in the burning sunshine without a drop of water for their thirst.

column2: At last, however, the people of Mecca became bold enough to go to Mohammed's uncle and tell him that Mohammed must cease preaching against their idols.
column3: At last, however, the people of Mecca became bold enough to go to Mohammed's uncle and tell him that Mohammed must cease preaching against their idols.

column2: Mohammed, however, indignantly refused, and went on preaching, and his uncle continued to protect him.
column3: Mohammed, however, indignantly refused, and went on preaching, and his uncle continued to protect him.

column2: At last Mohammed's enemies became so afraid of the success he was gaining that they decided they must have his life at all costs, and a plot was hatched against him.
column3: At last Mohammed's enemies became so afraid of the success he was gaining that they decided they must have his life at all costs, and a plot was hatched against him.

column2: He was saved by being warned of this and hidden away, but at last he and all his relatives who believed in his teachings, as most of them did, were driven from Mecca and were made outlaws.
column3: He was saved by being warned of this and hidden away, but at last he and all his relatives who believed in his teachings, as most of them did, were driven from Mecca and were made outlaws.

column2: His uncle's influence was so strong, however, that after Mohammed had lived in the mountains for three years, he and his relatives were allowed to return to Mecca.
column3: His uncle's influence was so strong, however, that after Mohammed had lived in the mountains for three years, he and his relatives were allowed to return to Mecca.

column2: But a great misfortune fell upon him, for his faithful wife Kadijah, whom he had loved deeply, and who was the first person to believe in him as a prophet, died, and left him inconsolable.
column3: But a great misfortune fell upon him, for his faithful wife Kadijah, whom he had loved deeply, and who was the first person to believe in him as a prophet, died, and left him inconsolable.

column2: His uncle also died, and Mohammed lost his protection.
column3: His uncle also died, and Mohammed lost his protection.

column2: Without the influence of his uncle Mecca again became too dangerous for Mohammed to remain in.

column3: When he tried to preach he was pelted with stones and mud and mocked on every side.

column2: He was consoled, however, by a dream in which he thought that he was preaching to certain spirits whose bodies were made of fire and who were known to the Meccans as _Djinns_.

column2: Because he had converted a number of men from the nearby town of Yathrib, Mohammed decided that a better opportunity was given him to teach his faith there than in Mecca itself, and in the year 622 A.D., he and his followers fled to Yathrib and were made welcome.
column3: Because he had converted a number of men from the nearby town of Yathrib, Mohammed decided that a better opportunity was given him to teach his faith there than in Mecca itself, and in the year six twenty two a d, he and his followers fled to Yathrib and were made welcome.

column3: This flight was called the "Hegira," and the date of it is very important to the Mohammedans, for their calendar dates from it, and for them is practically the beginning of time.

column2: In Yathrib the faith of Mohammed spread quickly and he received attention and reverence wherever he went.
column3: In Yathrib the faith of Mohammed spread quickly and he received attention and reverence wherever he went.

column2: And when he had a large following he desired to put up a house of prayer, or a temple which he called a mosque.

column2: And then for the first time began to be heard the call that to-day rings through so large a part of Asia and Africa, when the muezin, or crier, summons Mohammed's followers to prayer five times a day.

column3: It was not long before word came to Mecca that the man whom they had driven out had become powerful and mighty in a city not far off and that he was considered greater than a king among the disciples that followed him.

column2: Then the Meccans were again afraid, for they feared that some day Mohammed would appear with an army before their walls and revenge himself for the injuries that they had worked upon him.
column3: Then the Meccans were again afraid, for they feared that some day Mohammed would appear with an army before their walls and revenge himself for the injuries that they had worked upon him.

column3: It was a wild fight, for the battle was fought in a furious storm of rain and wind that beat like whips upon the faces of the soldiers as they dashed against each other.

column2: At first the fray went badly for the Mohammedans, for the enemy with their superior numbers forced them back.

column2: Everywhere Mohammed himself might have been seen, encouraging his followers and urging them to greater efforts. column2: With his army at his heels Mohammed went forth from Medinah and pitched his camp near Mount Uhud, only a bowshot away from his enemies.
column3: With his army at his heels Mohammed went forth from Medinah and pitched his camp near Mount u h u d, only a bowshot away from his enemies.

column2: As soon as it was dawn both sides were drawn up ready for battle--and then the Meccans saw a sight that had never before taken place on any battlefield--for at the call of the Muezin, which took place as though the Mohammedans were at home, the entire army bowed down in prayer.
column3: As soon as it was dawn both sides were drawn up ready for battle-and then the Meccans saw a sight that had never before taken place on any battlefield-for at the call of the Muezin, which took place as though the Mohammedans were at home, the entire army bowed down in prayer.

column2: At first the fight went well for the Mohammedans, but when a group of archers left their post to engage in the pursuit of the defeated Meccans this gave some of the enemy's cavalry a chance to surround or outflank Mohammed's soldiers.
column3: At first the fight went well for the Mohammedans, but when a group of archers left their post to engage in the pursuit of the defeated Meccans this gave some of the enemy's cavalry a chance to surround or outflank Mohammed's soldiers.

column2: The Meccans rallied and attacked him in front and the rear at the same time, and the day was lost.
column3: The Meccans rallied and attacked him in front and the rear at the same time, and the day was lost.

column2: However, the Meccans were too exhausted to pursue his men for a time and they believed that Mohammed himself had been slain, which was the first of their desires.
column3: However, the Meccans were too exhausted to pursue his men for a time and they believed that Mohammed himself had been slain, which was the first of their desires.

column2: So they returned to Mecca.
column3: So they returned to Mecca.

column2: For about two years there was little fighting, and then the Meccans planned an attack against Medinah, and advanced upon it with a large army.
column3: For about two years there was little fighting, and then the Meccans planned an attack against Medinah, and advanced upon it with a large army.

column2: And now Mohammed showed great military skill, for he conceived a plan that had never been known to the Arabians and that is still employed in modern warfare,--namely that of fighting from the protection of trenches.
column3: And now Mohammed showed great military skill, for he conceived a plan that had never been known to the Arabians and that is still employed in modern warfare,--namely that of fighting from the protection of trenches.

column2: With the hostile army almost upon them the Mohammedans worked furiously digging a deep ditch around the city, and so well did the ditch answer their purpose that the Meccans could accomplish nothing against them, but were obliged at last to turn tail and retreat to their own city.
column3: With the hostile army almost upon them the Mohammedans worked furiously digging a deep ditch around the city, and so well did the ditch answer their purpose that the Meccans could accomplish nothing against them, but were obliged at last to turn tail and retreat to their own city.

column2: In this siege there was a Jewish tribe in Medinah that had been treacherous to the Mohammedans, deserting them in their hour of need, and going over to the enemy.
column3: In this siege there was a Jewish tribe in Medinah that had been treacherous to the Mohammedans, deserting them in their hour of need, and going over to the enemy.

column2: This caused Mohammed great difficulty and might easily have brought about his defeat.
column3: This caused Mohammed great difficulty and might easily have brought about his defeat.

column2: So, when the fight was over, he took a large number of soldiers and advanced against this tribe which had taken refuge in a stronghold in the mountains.
column3: So, when the fight was over, he took a large number of soldiers and advanced against this tribe which had taken refuge in a stronghold in the mountains.

column2: When they saw the numbers that were against them a great fear came upon them and they surrendered to the Prophet without a fight, throwing themselves upon his mercy.
column3: When they saw the numbers that were against them a great fear came upon them and they surrendered to the Prophet without a fight, throwing themselves upon his mercy.

column2: They found, however, that from that mercy they could expect nothing, for all the men were put to death, and the women and children were sold into slavery.
column3: They found, however, that from that mercy they could expect nothing, for all the men were put to death, and the women and children were sold into slavery.

column2: Warfare between the Mohammedans and the Meccans continued in scattered outbursts until at last when both sides were weary of the struggle a treaty was made, and the Mohammedans were to be allowed to make a three day pilgrimage to Mecca to worship at the Kaabah or holy temple which was a part of Mohammed's religion.
column3: Warfare between the Mohammedans and the Meccans continued in scattered outbursts until at last when both sides were weary of the struggle a treaty was made, and the Mohammedans were to be allowed to make a three day pilgrimage to Mecca to worship at the Kaabah or holy temple which was a part of Mohammed's religion.

column2: This was considered by Mohammed as a great triumph for his cause. Determined now to spread his faith to the uttermost ends of the earth, he sent messengers to the rulers of all the civilized kingdoms that he knew.
column3: This was considered by Mohammed as a great triumph for his cause. Determined now to spread his faith to the uttermost ends of the earth, he sent messengers to the rulers of all the civilized kingdoms that he knew.

column2: One went to Heraclius, Emperor of the Romans, who was in Syria at the time; one to the Roman Governor of Egypt, one to the King of Abyssinia and one to each of the provinces of Gassan and Yamam that were also under Roman control.
column3: One went to Heraclius, Emperor of the romans, who was in Syria at the time; one to the Roman Governor of Egypt, one to the King of Abyssinia and one to each of the provinces of Gassan and Yamam that were also under Roman control.

column2: Then a ten year peace was agreed upon between the Meccans and the Mohammedans.
column3: Then a ten year peace was agreed upon between the Meccans and the Mohammedans.

column2: This, however, was not kept long, for the Meccans killed some of Mohammed's followers.
column3: This, however, was not kept long, for the Meccans killed some of Mohammed's followers.

column2: In fear for what they had done, they sent a deputation to request that he overlook what had taken place and allow the peace to continue as before, but Mohammed would give them no promises, and told his followers that the death of those who were slain by the Meccans would be amply avenged.
column3: In fear for what they had done, they sent a deputation to request that he overlook what had taken place and allow the peace to continue as before, but Mohammed would give them no promises, and told his followers that the death of those who were slain by the Meccans would be amply avenged.

column2: With great secrecy he prepared an army and went forth once more against the city with which he had been engaged in warfare for so many years.
column3: With great secrecy he prepared an army and went forth once more against the city with which he had been engaged in warfare for so many years.

column2: So swift was Mohammed's advance and so secret had his plans been kept that the Meccans knew nothing of his approach until they saw the camp-fires of his mighty army shining about their walls.
column3: So swift was Mohammed's advance and so secret had his plans been kept that the Meccans knew nothing of his approach until they saw the camp fires of his mighty army shining about their walls.

column2: They had no way of resisting his force for they had been surprised, and even if they could have prepared against him, their numbers were now far inferior to his own.
column3: They had no way of resisting his force for they had been surprised, and even if they could have prepared against him, their numbers were now far inferior to his own.

column2: And then came the greatest triumph of Mohammed's entire life, for the Meccans surrendered without conditions and promised to embrace the Mohammedan faith.
column3: And then came the greatest triumph of Mohammed's entire life, for the Meccans surrendered without conditions and promised to embrace the Mohammedan faith.

column2: With ropes and axes Mohammed's followers tore the stone idols of Mecca from their pedestals and hewed them to pieces, while the Meccans sorrowfully beheld the destruction.
column3: With ropes and axes Mohammed's followers tore the stone idols of Mecca from their pedestals and hewed them to pieces, while the Meccans sorrowfully beheld the destruction.

column2: And from that day to the present there has resounded over the city of Mecca five times each day the cry of "Allah Hu Akbar"--God is great, and the rest of the ritual calling the people to prayer.
column3: And from that day to the present there has resounded over the city of Mecca five times each day the cry of "Allah Hu Akbar"--God is great, and the rest of the ritual calling the people to prayer.

column2: Soon after this one desert tribe after another came under Mohammed's power, and finally all of Arabia had acknowledged him as God's prophet. He was planning to extend his religion still farther when a misfortune fell upon him that probably caused his death.
column3: Soon after this one desert tribe after another came under Mohammed's power, and finally all of Arabia had acknowledged him as God's prophet. He was planning to extend his religion still farther when a misfortune fell upon him that probably caused his death.

column2: With one of his followers he had partaken of a dish that had been prepared for him by a Jewish girl who hated him and all of his sect.
column3: With one of his followers he had partaken of a dish that had been prepared for him by a Jewish girl who hated him and all of his sect.

column2: The food was poisoned, and while Mohammed discovered it at once and ate but a single mouthful, the poison remained in his body.
column3: The food was poisoned, and while Mohammed discovered it at once and ate but a single mouthful, the poison remained in his body.

column2: Feeling that he was about to die he summoned his followers and preached to them a last sermon in which he exhorted them to obey all the rules of his religion, to treat their slaves and animals kindly and to beware of the works of the devils that were leagued against them.
column3: Feeling that he was about to die he summoned his followers and preached to them a last sermon in which he exhorted them to obey all the rules of his religion, to treat their slaves and animals kindly and to beware of the works of the devils that were leagued against them.

column2: Not a great while after this the Prophet fell ill of a fever, and at last died, to the great grief of those disciples who had known and loved him. Although he had always given his wealth to the poor so that he lived as meanly as the humblest of his followers--for this was one of the first things that he preached,--he was worshipped as being divine and had more than the homage of a mighty king.
column3: Not a great while after this the Prophet fell ill of a fever, and at last died, to the great grief of those disciples who had known and loved him. Although he had always given his wealth to the poor so that he lived as meanly as the humblest of his followers-for this was one of the first things that he preached,--he was worshipped as being divine and had more than the homage of a mighty king.

column2: In the hands of his fanatical followers the scimitar became the symbol of the Mohammedan faith and hundreds of thousands were conquered and made to acknowledge its power. To-day Mohammedanism is still one of the great religions of the world, and the name of the Prophet still sounds from thousands of mosques, when the muezin calls the people to prayer with the same words that were used while Mohammed was living.
column3: In the hands of his fanatical followers the scimitar became the symbol of the Mohammedan faith and hundreds of thousands were conquered and made to acknowledge its power. To day Mohammedanism is still one of the great religions of the world, and the name of the Prophet still sounds from thousands of mosques, when the muezin calls the people to prayer with the same words that were used while Mohammed was living.
